title: The Simplex Algorithm
text:
What is the simplex for?
The simplex algorithm solves linear problems in their standard form, i.e., the following type of optimization problems: \[\begin{align}
    \min_{x \in \mathbb{R}^n} \; & c^T x
    \\
    \text{s.t.} \; & A x = b
    \\
    & x \geq 0 \enspace,
\end{align}\] where \(c \in \mathbb{R}^n\), \(b \in \mathbb{R}^m\), and \(A \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}\).

The Optimality Conditions
The Karusk-Kuhn-Tucker optimality conditions write: \[\begin{align}
    & A^T \lambda + s = c
    \\
    & Ax = b
    \\
    & x \geq 0
    \\
    & \mu \geq 0
    \\
    & x_i \mu_i = 0 ,
    \enspace \text{for } i \in 1, \dots, n
    \enspace .
\end{align}\] Since the problem is convex, with linear equality and inequality constraints, the Karusk-Kuhn-Tucker conditions are necessary and sufficient for being a solution of the linear problem. In other words, if one can find a triplet \((x, \lambda, \mu)\) that satisfies the KKT conditions, then an optimal point \(x\).
